text: Welcome to the Deep Dive. Today we're exploring a theory that, well, it aims to explain just about everything. Yeah, it's pretty ambitious stuff. From the universe's basic structure, how your brain processes information, even where AI might be heading. Sounds a bit like science fiction, doesn't it? It does, but it's a serious proposal. It comes from a research group, Flixian, and they call it the Relativistic Scalar Vector Plenum, RSVP for short. RSVP theory. Okay. And what's really fascinating, I think, is how they weave together ideas from physics, theoretical physics, neuroscience, and AI research. It's all meant to be one coherent framework. And where are we getting this information? You mentioned Flixian. Yeah, exactly. We've got a whole set of their recent papers and even some pretty interesting informal notes they've put out, all very current, July 2025. Okay. So our mission today is to really get into this ambitious, maybe even audacious theory. We'll look at the core ideas, how it wants to redefine things like consciousness, the cosmos, and why they think it offers a better path for AI. You know, more biologically plausible, maybe more ethically sound. That's the claim. All right. Prepare for some serious mind bending, I think. Decorate. So let's start at the heart of it. RSVP theory. Yeah. You said it's built on, what, three fundamental fields? Yeah. Like building blocks? Exactly. Three core components. Think of them as the basis for this new conceptual reality they're proposing. Okay. What are they? Well, RSVP models pretty much any system, physical, cognitive, even narrative structures, like stories through how these three fields interact. And this happens over, you know, standard four-dimensional space time. Right. So first you've got the scalar field. The Greek letter phi, oh way, this is like the what? Right. Semantic density, energy concentration, maybe neural activation strength. It's the substance, the meaning in a given spot. But what? Second, the vector field, little v. This captures flow, information flow, attention direction, entropy gradients even. It's the how or where to. It directs movement, influence. The directionality. Makes sense. And finally, there's the entropy field. This quantifies the ambiguity, the disorder, the uncertainty. You know, how much chaos or how much order is there right here, right now? Chaos versus order. And a really key idea in RSVP is that the system is always, always trying to minimize this entropy. It wants to move towards more coherent, more structured states. Okay. So those are the three pieces. What does it mean for how they actually work together? How do they interact? Yeah. They're not just sitting there separately. They're dynamically coupled. That means they constantly influence each other through things like diffusion, you know, spreading out, advection being carried along by the flow, and feedback loops, lots of feedback loops. And the evolution, how these fields change over time, it's governed by equations. Coupled partial differential equations, actually. It's a bit like how physics describes fluids moving or particles interacting. So there's real math behind it. Oh, yeah. Definitely. And the goal is always that drive towards lower entropy. That's what allows order, structure, meaning to emerge from what might look like just random noise at first. Okay. Interesting. Immersions from reducing entropy. Let's try and make this more concrete. Our brains. How does this apply to neuroscience? Right. So the brain. Neuroscience has puzzled over cortical columns for a long time. Those vertical clusters of neurons. Right. Exactly. You can see them anatomically. But figuring out their consistent function has been tricky, especially because they vary quite a bit, you know, between species, even between individuals. Horton and Adams pointed this out back in 2005. So they're not identical units doing the same job everywhere. Doesn't seem like it. And that raises the question, if they aren't fixed functional units, what are they? Okay. And RSVP has an answer. It offers a reinterpretation. RSVP sees columns not as rigid structures, but as, get this, emergent coherence tiles. Emergent coherence tiles. Okay. Unpack that. Think of them like dynamic patterns. They just sort of arise, self-organize from the interplay of those three fields, die, V, and S. But they're shaped by specific constraints. Like what's coming in from our senses. Exactly. Sensory inputs or even the brain's energy budget. The scalar field, it forms these low entropy attractor spots where the entropy S gets minimized, where information gets really focused and ordered. And that's what forms these tiles, these apparent columns. Ah, so their variability makes sense then. They're context-dependent solutions, not fixed hardware. Precisely. It depends on the conditions, not some rigid genetic blueprint. That's a really different way of looking at brain structure. It is. And it connects nicely with another idea called geometric Bayesianism with sparse heuristics, or GBSH. GBSH. Which basically argues that the brain's amazing efficiency, its sparsity, comes from metabolic constraints. It has to save energy. Because the brain uses so much power. A huge amount. And studies, like by pervs and colleagues more recently, show these conserved ratios column width to cortical thickness across different species. GBSH and RSVP suggest these ratios aren't genetic dictates, but geometric scaling laws, driven by minimizing energy. Wow. Okay. And you mentioned something else, amplitwist operators. That sounds very sci-fi. Yeah, it does sound a bit out there, doesn't it? But it's a really neat mathematical idea they use. What do they do? Well, what's cool is they combine two things. Amplitude scaling. Like turning the volume up or down? Kind of, yeah. Like gain control in your senses. Yeah. Adjusting sensitivity. And they combine that with phase rotation. Phase rotation. And like waves. Or tuning. Exactly. Like a neuron changing its tuning or its oscillation pattern. So these operators, they apply a local transformation. They sort of twist and scale the neural representations. Imagine zooming in or out on a mental map or rotating your perspective on something. And the idea is that by composing these operations recursively, layer after layer in the cortex, the brain can perform really complex functions. Spatial reasoning. Grouping objects together visually. So the brain's flexibility isn't from fixed modules, but from dynamically tweaking these geometric transformations. That's the argument. It's a much more fluid picture of how the brain computes and adapts. Fascinating. Okay, let's pivot from biology to artificial intelligence. Yeah. AI. Right. The current big thing is transformer architectures, right? Powering models like ChatGPT, Bernie. They rely heavily on this mechanism called self-attention. They do. But RSVP theory or affliction seems quite critical of that approach. What's their issue with self-attention? Yeah. They have a paper called Attention Considered Harmful. Strong title. Oh, okay. Their argument is basically that while transformers work well on current hardware, like GPUs, that dense self-attention mechanism, it's fundamentally not how biology does it. They argue it's more like a graph neural network over a fully connected graph, or maybe a shallow recurrent network with a fixed look ahead. And this, they say, violates something crucial. The natural sparsity principle, NSP. Natural sparsity principle. You mentioned sparsity with the brain's energy use. Tell us more about this principle. So, the NSP basically states that biological cognition has to be sparse. There are critical constraints forcing it. Like the energy cost. Exactly. That's number one. Metabolic cost. Your brain burns something like 10 to the 14 ATP molecules per second. It's incredibly expensive. It absolutely cannot afford dense all-to-all computations like transformers often do. Sparse activation is key to saving energy. So, dense attention is just too wasteful biologically? Way too wasteful, and creates redundant calculations. Second constraint, environmental noise. Biology operates in a noisy world. Sparse pathways actually improve the signal-to-noise ratio, makes the system more robust. Okay. And third? Thermodynamic gradients. That drive to minimize entropy we talked about, that naturally favors sparse ordered representations over dense, potentially chaotic ones. So, transformers are powerful, maybe computationally, but they're not thinking like us because they violate these fundamental biological or even physical constraints. That's the core critique, yeah. Yeah. They're not respecting the sparsity that seems inherent to natural intelligence. So, what's the RSVP alternative for AI then? If not attention, then what? They propose a few interconnected ideas. One is relevance activation theory, or RAT. RAT. Okay. Here, attention isn't a built-in mechanism. It's an emergent property that arises from those RSVP fields interacting recursively. How does that work? The scalar field, F-wa, encodes the meaning, the semantics. The entropy field, S, helps suppress noise and guide the system towards sparse solutions. And the vector field, V, directs the flow of activation, the spotlight, if you will. It emerges from the dynamics. Interesting. And you mentioned another one. Yeah. Aspect relegation theory, or RT. This tries to explain how we shift between different modes of thinking. You know, slow, deliberate, System 2 thinking versus fast, automatic, System 1 processing. Kahneman's concepts. Right. Exactly. In RSVP terms, RT describes this shift as the system learning to reduce entropy gradients and stabilize the vector field pathways for tasks we practice a lot. Things become automatic because the flow gets streamlined and efficient. So it's about learning efficient pathways within these fields. Exactly. Yeah. Completely different from just adding more layers or parameters. It's a fundamentally different architectural approach grounded in these field dynamics and efficiency principles. And does this different approach tie into the challenge of controlling AI, this idea of a controlled AI takeoff? Absolutely. That's a huge part of the motivation, I think. The question is critical. How do we guide AI that's becoming potentially super intelligent? Right. How do we keep it aligned? RSVP contributes to what they frame as a three-tiered framework for a controlled AI takeoff. It's quite sophisticated. Three tiers. Okay. What are they? Tier one is criticality. This is about when an AI system should act or maybe even learn. The idea is to tune AI systems to operate near the edge of chaos. The edge of chaos. Like not too rigid, not too random. Precisely. It's thought to be a state where information processing is optimal. And here's the really interesting part. They suggest that collective human preferences, maybe even nonverbal signals like societal mood or protests, could actually modulate these criticality thresholds. So society could collectively tap the brakes or hit the gas on AI development. That's the idea. Dynamically adjusting the AI's operating point based on collective sentiment. Wow. Okay. Tier one is when? What's tier two? Tier two is predictive coding. This manages how the AI acts. It's inspired by how our brains work, constantly trying to predict sensory input and minimize prediction errors. Like the Bayesian brain idea. Very much so. AI systems would continuously model and predict human preferences. Crucially, they penalize themselves for being overconfident in their predictions about us. So they have to be cautious about assuming what we want. Exactly. And explicit human feedback votes, dialogues, collective decisions could directly adjust these internal predictions. If the AI's predictions about our preferences are way off, maybe training gets paused automatically. Built-in alignment checks. Okay. And tier three. Tier three brings an RSVP directly. This is about ensuring what is meaningful. It models the AI's decisions and outputs, not just as data, but as ripples in this underlying semantic plenum, this field of meaning. Okay. So you'd use RSVP metrics, things like field coherence or nogentropy, which is like the opposite of entropy, a measure of order to make sure that the AI's growth and actions actually preserve meaning. That it doesn't just generate technically correct nonsense or pursue goals that are semantically hollow or harmful from a human perspective. So it's about embedding purpose and meaning directly into the AI's operational principles using this field theory. That's the goal. Yeah. As a radical idea. And RSVP seems to take that idea and run with it. Give it an engine. Exactly. RSVP, especially when they combine it with another concept they call Tartan. Tartan. What's that? Trajectory aware recursive tiling with annotated noise. Quite a mouthful. Okay. But basically, Tartan helps RSVP operationalize Barber's idea. In RSVP, remember, the universe's state at any moment is just the configuration of those VNS fields. Right. So time isn't some external clock ticking away. It's generated from within the system. Right. It emerges from the interactions of the fields and this process of entropic structuring, of things becoming more ordered. So the flow of time we feel, that's just an emergent property. Yeah. A consequence of these fields changing. That's precisely the idea. And Tartan helps visualize this by recursively partitioning the universe into these coherence tiles we talked about the brain. Each tile has its own local field state, its own scale, its own entropy level. Like little pockets of reality? Sort of. Each one acts like a mini time capsule. Its internal structure implies a past state and suggests a future trajectory. So time becomes localized and scale dependent. This whole framework, they call it the Aletheos canonical form or ACF, and that constant drive for change, the pressure that makes things happen, comes from something they call universal origins theory, UET. Does it offer a different story for how, say, galaxies formed, how we got the large-scale structure we see in the universe? It does.
